image.altText: A girl sits up in bed, hugging her knees to her chest. Her face is blurred by a sheet of tempered glass.

items.synopsis: Florence is among hundreds of Australians who have allegedly been sexually assaulted in mental health wards. As her parents consider legal action against the hospital, she wants her story told to keep others safe.

title.children: Teenage girl allegedly raped while being treated in Perth Children's Hospital mental health ward

image.altText: Anika Wells speaks in parliament.

items.synopsis: The federal Labor minister was diagnosed with an autoimmune disease during her first pregnancy and says, like others with invisible diseases, she does not want people drawing their own conclusions about her illness.

title.children: Why Anika Wells doesn't publicly name her chronic illness

image.altText: A middle-aged woman in a purple outfit and weading glasses sits on a plush chair with her hands in her lap.

items.synopsis: The Reserve Bank has left the cash rate unchanged at 4.1 per cent for the fourth month in a row at Michele Bullock's first meeting as governor, but warns another rate hike may be needed as uncertainty grows around oil prices.

title.children: RBA keeps rates steady at 4.1 per cent but warns future increases may be likely to tame inflation

image.altText: Two people sit on a stage smiling, both wearing t-shirts that say Vote No to the Voice of Division

items.synopsis: More than 1,000 vocal No supporters are urged by Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price and Nyunggai Warren Mundine not to get complacent ahead of the historic referendum on an Indigenous Voice to Parliament.

title.children: Price and Mundine issue rallying cry to No crowd in Perth as Voice vote draws closer

image.altText: An aerial shot of the Gorgon gas project on the coast of Western Australia.

items.synopsis: Australia may be a quarry to the world, and the mining of its natural resources might underpin our national budget. But we can and must demand better corporate ethics than this, writes Linton Besser.

title.children: A 'sham' workforce in WA has exposed the shadowy ways of global oil and gas — and workers are paying the price

image.altText: flames light up night sky behind houses

items.synopsis: Bushfire emergencies are unfolding in multiple states, with residents of Abernethy in NSW told it is "too late to leave".  Fires in Victoria and Tasmania have been downgraded. Follow live.

title.children: Fires in NSW reach emergency level as Victoria, Tasmanian fires downgraded

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Country Fire Authority Chief Officer Jason Heffernan says this summer will be hotter and drier, and everyone should be prepared. "For East Gippsland communities, if we do see rainfall totals as we've had today, we'll probably seek to pause that bushfire risk, probably for a few weeks, but don't be fooled. Let's not be complacent here ," he says. "The bush will dry out, the warm weather will continue to come about. In fact, we've heard from the Bureau through the Spring Seasonal outlook that we're ... four times more likely to have higher than average temperatures over spring right arcoss Australia. "While it will be a reprieve for firefighters today, [and] it will bring some reprieve to communities from fire conditions for the next couple of weeks, we can't be complacent. We must be constantly thinking about bushfire as we head into this summer." He urges everyone to have a bushfire survival plan and start preparing their property for the coming season.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Australians urged to update emergency survival plans

children.content: Country Fire Authority Chief Officer
Jason Heffernan
says this summer will be
hotter and drier
, and everyone should be prepared.
"For East Gippsland communities, if we do see rainfall totals as we've had today, we'll probably seek to pause that bushfire risk, probably for a few weeks, but don't be fooled.
Let's not be complacent here
," he says.
"The bush will dry out, the warm weather will continue to come about. In fact, we've heard from the Bureau through the Spring Seasonal outlook that we're ...
four times more likely to have higher than average temperatures over spring
right arcoss Australia.

"While it will be a reprieve for firefighters today, [and] it will bring some reprieve to communities from fire conditions for the next couple of weeks, we can't be complacent. We must be constantly thinking about bushfire as we head into this summer."
He urges everyone to have a
bushfire survival plan
and
start preparing their property
for the coming season.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The emergency warnings in Victorian townships Loch Sport and Seacombe have been downgraded to Advice level. "There is currently no threat to you," authorities say. "Stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. Don't get complacent, the situation may change quickly." Authorities advise residents in these areas to continue to monitor weather conditions and warnings as the fire is not yet under control. Earlier, CFA Chief Officer Jason Heffernan said while there were high winds, rain was starting to fall on the fire grounds. "I am very confident that the firefighters are doing everything they can to stop the progress and contain that fire," Heffernan said. "They are very much going to be assisted by the rainfall."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Emergency warnings in Loch Sport and Seacombe downgraded

children.content: The emergency warnings in Victorian townships
Loch Sport
and
Seacombe
have been downgraded to Advice level.
"There is currently no threat to you," authorities say.
"Stay informed and plan for what you will do if the situation changes. Don't get complacent, the situation may change quickly."
Authorities advise residents in these areas to
continue to monitor weather conditions and warnings
as the fire is
not yet under control.
Earlier, CFA Chief Officer
Jason Heffernan
said while there were high winds, rain was starting to fall on the fire grounds.
"I am very confident that the firefighters are doing everything they can to stop the progress and contain that fire," Heffernan said.
"They are very much going to be assisted by the rainfall."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Reporting by Georgia-Lenton-Williams Some regional community members say they can't download the Vic Emergency app because it is incompatible with their phones. Gippsland local Trevor has told ABC Statewide Drive his wife's phone was apparently too new to operate the app. “I've got a daughter and a son who live on the Briag Stratford Road… fairly close to the fire,” he said. “My wife and I, we grew up at Loch Sport and currently in Paynesville we're under flood watch, so it would be nice to have the app.” Several people have been contacting the program to report similar issues downloading the app. Emergency Management Victoria said earlier issues with the push notifications have been resolved and urge people to use multiple sources of information during emergencies.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Regional residents report having trouble accessing Vic Emergency app

children.content: Reporting by Georgia-Lenton-Williams
Some regional community members say they
can't download the Vic Emergency app
because it is incompatible with their phones.
Gippsland local Trevor has told ABC Statewide Drive his wife's phone was apparently
too new to operate the app
“I've got a daughter and a son who live on the Briag Stratford Road… fairly close to the fire,” he said.
“My wife and I, we grew up at Loch Sport and currently in Paynesville we're under flood watch, so it would be nice to have the app.”
Several people have been contacting the program to report similar issues downloading the app.
Emergency Management Victoria said earlier issues with the
push notifications
have been resolved and urge people to
use multiple sources of information
during emergencies.

image.altText: City office-workers and passers-by watch the ASX board in Sydney

items.synopsis: The local share market suffered heavy losses as investors bet on interest rates staying higher for longer, while the Australian dollar slumped to its weakest level since November, despite increased bets the Reserve Bank will lift interest rates again in the next few months.

title.children: ASX wipes out all its gains of 2023, RBA keeps rates on hold but doesn't rule out future increase — as it happened

image.altText: Kemuel Tamwoy sits in from of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander flags

items.synopsis: Indigenous leaders in Cape York and the Gulf say the Voice to Parliament can make a difference, provided it has strong grassroots participation.

title.children: 'It's got to be someone local': How some Indigenous leaders want the Voice to operate

image.altText: Illustration of Australia with night sky and stars in background and yellow circle in middle of Australia.

items.synopsis: On October 14, every Australian will be asked to answer a yes or no question. What you write on the ballot paper will determine whether our constitution is changed for the first time in more than four decades. Here's everything you need to know before you vote.

title.children: Your Voice voting cheat sheet: All your referendum questions, answered

image.altText: Sue Hedley holding grey cat with crates behind

items.synopsis: A rescue group calls for Qantas to reconsider its animal flight rules, with concerns more could be euthanased in WA's Pilbara.

title.children: Rescue group fears animals will be put down if Qantas sticks to heat rules

image.altText: Smoke burning over homes

items.synopsis: An emergency warning is issued for two out-of-control bushfires in New South Wales that are threatening homes and properties.

title.children: Residents told it's too late to leave as out-of-control bushfires are upgraded to emergency level

image.altText: Close up of faces of a man and his adult son wearing bike helmets on a sunny day.

items.synopsis: Ed Croft, who testified before the disability royal commission, says his son experienced significant problems in mainstream schooling and parents need to be able to choose.

title.children: 'Their only solution was to lock him in a cupboard': Dad dismayed by royal commission recommendation to close special schools

image.altText: A circle of rocks surrounding a hole in the ground in an outback paddock.

items.synopsis: Police say they are investigating the apparent desecration of the cultural heritage site, which has hurt and angered the area's Aboriginal custodians.

title.children: 'Another insult' as Indigenous well filled with concrete in outback Queensland

image.altText: Melbourne Demons AFLW player Libby Birch has a look of concentration after executing a handball in a game

items.synopsis: AFLW player Libby Birch wants more women to feel comfortable talking about their breasts, while more options are now available to help those playing contact sport avoid injury.

title.children: Finding the right fit: Why breasts are a still a 'taboo' topic in sport, and what we can do to protect them

image.altText: A young woman in a fluoro vest with pink glasses standing between trains.

items.synopsis: Chelsea Taylor thought university was the only option after school. But after three unfinished degrees and $30,000 in student debt, she felt "really, really lost" — until she became a train driver.

title.children: After racking up a big student debt, Chelsea became a train driver. She says career advice is limiting teenagers

image.altText: A woman with blonde hair cries while sitting in a police interview room

items.synopsis: Biannca Edmunds has been sentenced to 26 years' jail after a botched assassination plan she hatched with her husband, targeting her ex-partner, resulted in both mens' deaths.

title.children: Judge says woman showed 'extreme' entitlement by plotting to kill her ex-partner over custody issues

image.altText: Split screen image of a woman and a man on ABC's Q+A.

items.synopsis: As Senator Malarndirri McCarthy reveals the moment she felt most "disempowered", a debate focused on who the Voice will help takes over Q+A.

title.children: 'Disadvantage' locked into the constitution or 'significant moment'? Voice debate heats up on Q+A

image.altText: An elderly woman skydiving with a man.

items.synopsis: Dorothy Hoffner did her dive on Sunday in Chicago, hoping to claim the title once owned by late South Australian woman Irene O'Shea.

title.children: Chicago woman, 104, skydives aiming for record of world's oldest skydiver — a title once held by an Australian woman

image.altText: Composite image of two photos of a man - a selfie with him smoking a cigar and a mugshot. Around him are passport stamps.

items.synopsis: The work undercover operatives and sources do is a key weapon against organised crime. These men say our law enforcement agencies have abandoned them.

title.children: This Australian is sitting in a foreign prison cell. He's ready to come clean about his life undercover

image.altText: Kacey and Layne stand together smiling on a suburban street.

items.synopsis: Less than half of the federal government's promised urgent care clinics have opened, months after the policy was supposed to be delivered.

title.children: After waiting six hours in an emergency department, Kasey is wondering where her city's Urgent Care Clinic is

image.altText: Three people stand in the background, between two purple and white YES signs

items.synopsis: The Yes23 campaign has been asked to keep signs for the Yes vote coloured in purple and white away from Australian Electoral Commission signage.

title.children: Yes23 campaign warned over signs which could 'mislead' voters at polling stations

image.altText: A woman in a winter coat and glasses.

items.synopsis: A District Court Civil Judge has granted an application to prevent an Adelaide woman accused of murdering her parents from accessing their estate.

title.children: Woman accused of killing parents denied access to their estate

image.altText: high school with fence

items.synopsis: A female student is in police custody and a male student is transported to hospital in a stable condition following a violent altercation involving a knife at Caloundra State High School.

title.children: Sunshine Coast high school goes into lockdown as violent altercation puts student in hospital

image.altText: A blonde, bespectacled woman and two men in suits walk down a city street.

items.synopsis: Nicole Louise Bourne was charged with more than 200 offences in 2020. Today, just as a six-day trial was to begin, she has pleaded guilty to 39 charges.

title.children: Magistrate furious over 'outrageous' waste of time after 11th-hour plea from pet store owner

image.altText: Stan Grant in a suit and short

items.synopsis: Michael Steven Davis, 41, allegedly used his Facebook and Twitter profiles to threaten "serious harm" in May.

title.children: Man accused of abusing Stan Grant online has three charges dropped, offers to apologise

image.altText: nsw police at a crime scene where a woman was found inside a home in Bankstown

items.synopsis: Police allege the 31-year-old man stabbed his mother to death, killed her cat and set the family home on fire in Sydney's south west.

title.children: Son allegedly killed mother a day after being granted bail for attacking her, court told

image.altText: A man in a woven headdress stands in a field, looking solemn

items.synopsis: Japan's Ainu people have their own history, languages and culture. But, as the victims of colonialism, assimilation and discrimination, much of that identity has been lost. This is the story of their fight to be recognised.

title.children: For years, Japan tried to keep their existence a secret. But the Ainu people refuse to disappear

image.altText: Donald Trump sits in court and looks straight ahead. The gallery behind him is full of people.

items.synopsis: Donald Trump is fighting a civil lawsuit that could cost him control of his prized properties and his freedom to do business in New York. Here's what happened on day one of the trial.

title.children: Trump doesn't show up to court unless he's forced. Here's why he chose to appear at his fraud trial

image.altText: Chris Minns wearing a high-vis vest

items.synopsis: The Minns government has faced calls to allow for pill testing at events in the state following the deaths of two men who attended the Knockout Outdoor music festival in Western Sydney last weekend.

title.children: 'A toxic combination': NSW premier issues drugs warning as man charged over festival death

image.altText: A woman, covering her head in a blanket, sits looking upward, surrounded by barbed wire

items.synopsis: Several hundred migrants in southern Mexico wait for buses to the country's north in a new government program meant to help manage the number of people entering the country.

title.children: Mexico sends buses to collect migrants as thousands reach US border

image.altText: Benedict Cumberbatch in red pyjamas sits in a cross legged meditation position in front of a bright background

items.synopsis: Theatrics, decorative wallpaper and the good in people: Wes Anderson brings his whimsy to Roald Dahl's The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar

title.children: In just 39 minutes Wes Anderson brings The Wonderful Story of Henry Sugar to life
